qas.question: Why is efficiency sometimes lost in phosphor-based LEDs?

answers.text: heat loss from the Stokes shift

qas.question: What do phosphor-based LEDs luminous efficacies depend on?

answers.text: the spectral distribution of the resultant light output

qas.question: What are some of the luminous efficacies of yellow phosphor based white LED compared to blue?
What is the most popular method for making high-intensity white LEDs?
What type of emitter is used in phosphor-based white LED methods?

plausible_answers.text: heat loss from the Stokes shift

qas.question: Why is efficiency never lost in phosphor-based LEDs?

plausible_answers.text: spectral distribution of the resultant light output and the original wavelength

qas.question: What don't phosphor-based LEDs luminous efficacies depend on?
What are some of the luminous efficacies of yellow phosphor based red LED compared to blue?
What type of emitter is used in non-phosphor-based white LED methods?

context: Phosphor-based LED efficiency losses are due to the <a0_0><b5_0>heat loss from the Stokes shift<b5_0/><a0_0/> and also other phosphor-related degradation issues. Their luminous efficacies compared to normal LEDs depend on <a1_0>the <b6_0>spectral distribution of the resultant light output<a1_0/> and the original wavelength<b6_0/> of the LED itself. For example, the luminous efficacy of a typical YAG yellow <b7_0>phosphor<b7_0/> based white LED ranges from <a2_0>3 to 5 times the luminous efficacy<a2_0/> of the original blue LED because of the human eye's greater sensitivity to yellow than to blue (as modeled in the luminosity function). Due to the simplicity of manufacturing the <a3_0>phosphor method<a3_0/> is still the most popular method for making high-intensity white LEDs. The design and production of a light source or light fixture using a <a4_0><b8_0>monochrome<b8_0/><a4_0/> emitter with phosphor conversion is simpler and cheaper than a complex RGB system, and the majority of high-intensity white LEDs presently on the market are manufactured using phosphor light conversion.
